issue.body: Some issues (e.g. #11441 ) may be related to "typescript" or something. should we create a label?

body:
This should be pretty easy-- instead of fixing the first token in the VariableDeclaration node, we should fix the first token that specifically says `var`. `sourceCode.getFirstToken` supports a filter predicate.

The tricky bit will be writing a test case with a fixture. :smile:

Marking as accepted.

> The tricky bit will be writing a test case with a fixture.

The question is, we are not using typescript for parsing. what do you think of just not autofix this case, if  the first token is not `var`? in this way -- it could be seen as a guard, not a bugfix.

issue.title: Fix: no-var fixed to incorrect code (fixes #11441)

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**
fixes #11441 

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

the issue is related to typescript.
should this be a bugfix, or enhancement?

body:
~~Another issue here is: I remember (not very sure) eslint will not apply the fix, if the fixed code not parsing successfully.
But it seems not working as expected.~~

ignore it. it's not true.

> The question is, we are not using typescript for parsing. what do you think of just not autofix this case, if the first token is not `var`? in this way -- it could be seen as a guard, not a bugfix.

I think if we just use something like `sourceCode.getFirstToken(node, t => t.value === "var")`, we could treat this as a bug fix and we wouldn't need to suppress the autofix. (I left a note with a little more detail in the PR.)

issue.title: `no-var` fixer breaks on declared vars in @typescript-eslint

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).

    This template is for bug reports. If you are here for another reason, please see below:

    1. To propose a new rule: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/new-rules
    2. To request a rule change: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/rule-changes
    3. To request a change that is not a bug fix, rule change, or new rule: https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/changes
    4. If you have any questions, please stop by our chatroom: https://gitter.im/eslint/eslint

    Note that leaving sections blank will make it difficult for us to troubleshoot and we may have to close the issue.
-->

The fixer for `no-var` just replaces the first token in the VariableDeclaration with `let` or `const`:
https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/c021117915d5d23399233f761a237e138f1854af/lib/rules/no-var.js#L308 

This is valid in JS, but in TS that first token can be `declare`, which breaks the fixer.

In the discussion over in https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues/410, @platinumazure suggested that this could be fixed in `eslint` instead:

```js
const varToken = sourceCode.getFirstToken(node, { filter: t => t.value === node.kind });
```

**Tell us about your environment**

* **ESLint Version:** 5.16.0
* **Node Version:** 11.12.0
* **npm Version:** 6.1.0

**What parser (default, Babel-ESLint, etc.) are you using?** @typescript-eslint/parser

**Please show your full configuration:**

<details>
<summary>Configuration</summary>

<!-- Paste your configuration below: -->
```js
{
    "parser": "@typescript-eslint/parser",
    "rules": {
        "no-var": 2
    }
}
```

</details>

**What did you do? Please include the actual source code causing the issue, as well as the command that you used to run ESLint.**

<!-- Paste the source code below: -->
```ts
declare var blah: number;
```

<!-- Paste the command you used to run ESLint: -->
```bash
eslint --ext js,jsx,ts,tsx --fix .
```

**What did you expect to happen?**
It should fix the code into:

```ts
declare let blah: number;
```

**What actually happened? Please include the actual, raw output from ESLint.**
It fixed the code into:

```ts
let var blah: number;
```

**Are you willing to submit a pull request to fix this bug?**
Unfortunately not. However, @platinumazure suggested a fix:

```js
const varToken = sourceCode.getFirstToken(node, { filter: t => t.value === node.kind });
```

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->

**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**

[X] Bug fix
<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->
[issue #11699 ](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/11699)
<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

Fixed the autofix for the following cases:

```js
let {a, b} = c, d;
```

```js
let {a, b, c} = {}, e, f;
```
```
let {a, b} = {}, c = 0;
c = 1;
```

by moving and modifying logic from `checkGroup()` to `VariableDeclaration()`

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**
